#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Boston/Fenway-Kenmore
#Text=The
#Text=Fenway-Kenmore neighborhood is named after Kenmore
#Text=Square , and after the Fens , both of which it encompasses .
#Text=Kenmore Square is the area 's dynamic urban center .
#Text=This is where trains arrive and shops light up in an effort to entice passing customers .
#Text=High above , the Citgo sign ( now a historical landmark ) keeps a watchful eye on new arrivals as they make their way through these congested crossroads .
#Text=Neighborhoods
#Text=Kenmore : The area is quite urban , but all the green space makes it feel much more livable than you might think .
#Text=Like many other areas of Boston , Kenmore is in the middle of a building boom .
#Text=The closeness of the parks and gardens help to balance the city and nature experiences .
#Text=The Fens : Just south and away from the square lies the hushed Fens , a study in contrasts .
#Text=The Muddy River meanders through rustling reeds and shady , sloping lawns and gardens .
#Text=Rustic stone bridges and benches offer a place to linger , to admire the water and all its inhabitants .
#Text=The Fens also work to separate Kenmore from the sprawling medical complex , Longwood Medical Area .
#Text=Turkeys have even been known call the place home .
#Text=If you see one , watch out , they can be mean !
#Text=Longwood : An extremely dense cluster of hospitals and schools .
#Text=By public transit
#Text=In this part of town the Green line will usually be your best bet , and Kenmore is the station to know .
#Text=The B , C , and D Green line branches all stop here , and a large glass bus depot hovers above .
#Text=It 's also the closest stop to the Fenway Park .
#Text=From here the B line continues outbound to Blandford Street , BU East , and BU Central before entering Allston .
#Text=While the D branch passes through Fenway before entering the independent town of Brookline .
#Text=The E branch is great for visiting area museums , it stops at Symphony , Museum of Fine Arts , Longwood , and Brigham Circle stations .
#Text=The Orange line shares the Ruggles and Massachusetts Avenue stations with several other neighborhoods , but you wo n't find these stops quite as helpful .
#Text=The E branch of the Green line is closer to top sights , however , the Orange line can be a good alternative if the E line is experiencing service issues .
#Text=Ruggles also serves as a stop for Commuter Rail lines headed to Providence/Stoughton , Franklin , and Needham .
#Text=Another Commuter Rail station ( especially popular on game days ) is Yawkey , which serves the Framingham/Worcester line .
#Text=It 's quite close to Fenway Park as well .
#Text=By far the most popular bus route is the #57 .
#Text=Running from Kenmore Square down Comm Ave , into Allston and eventually ending in Watertown .
#Text=Also leaving from Kenmore , the #60 and #65 run less frequently into Brookline , while the #8 and #19 take you through the Longwood area and the South End via Ruggles .
#Text=The CT2 and #47 busses can be picked up in Boston University , and take you over the BU bridge into Kendall and Central squares in Cambridge .
#Text=The #39 also runs constantly down Huntington Ave taking you to either inbound to Back Bay or outbound to Mission Hill .
#Text=Ruggles is a also a major bus hub , fanning lines out citywide .
#Text=By car
#Text=For those with deep pockets and endless patience , take the Kenmore Square/Fenway exit from Storrow Drive and follow signs to your destination .
#Text=Do n't even look for on street parking , go right for a garage .
#Text=You 're looking at around $ 15 - 20 an hour to park , and on game days expect to be gouged $ 100 or more for parking , if it 's even available in the first place .
#Text=The twisting roads , congested traffic , and aggressive drivers should all be steering you towards forgoing your four wheels and taking the T instead .
#Text=See
#Text=The Museum of Fine Arts ( MFA ) , 465 Huntington Ave ( T : Museum of Fine Arts ) , ☏ +1 617-267-9300 .
#Text=W - F 10AM-10PM , Sa - Tu 10AM-5PM .

#Text=As the fourth largest museum in the US , the Museum of Fine Art is known for its impressive assortment of French Impressionist paintings as well as its extraordinary collection of ancient Egyptian , Greek , and Roman art .
#Text=The MFA also has one of the largest collections of Japanese art outside of Japan .
#Text=A new modernist Art of the Americas Wing was completed in 2010 , architected by Norman Foster .
#Text=A visitor could simply rush through the highlights in a few hours , or linger all day and take it all in properly .
#Text=The museum also has a great collection of early American art , including the portrait of George Washington used on the dollar bills you might find in your wallet right now .
#Text=$ 25 , seniors and students $ 23 .
#Text=The Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum , 25 Evans Way ( T : Museum of Fine Arts ) , ☏ +1 617-566-1401 .
#Text=Tu - Su 11AM-5PM .
#Text=Not your typical museum experience .
#Text=Modeled after a 15th century Venetian palazzo , the museum displays Mrs. Gardner 's evocative home as it was when she lived here .
#Text=She collected many masterworks , unappreciated at the time , and displayed them in a most unconventional manner .
#Text=The juxtaposition of artworks from different cultures and time periods still delights visitors today .
#Text=While the museum contains works by famous artists like Rembrandt and Velazquez , the main attraction is not in any particular work , but in how each room is laid out :
#Text=Not only the paintings and tapestries , but also the furniture and architecture in every corner of the building are valuable works of art .
#Text=Gardner 's will stipulates the works of art must remain in her original arrangement .
#Text=This is the reason one wall remains blank , after an unbelievable art heist in early 1990 .
#Text=Thirteen pieces were stolen , valued at over $ 500 million dollars , the works of art remain missing to this day . $ 15 adult , $ 12 senior , $ 5 student .
#Text=Massachusetts Historical Society ( MHS ) , 1154 Boylston Street ( T : Hynes Convention Center ) , ☏ +1 617-536-1608 .
#Text=M - Sa 10AM-4PM .
#Text=Founded in 1791 , the Massachusetts Historical Society is the nation 's oldest historical society .
#Text=The collections of the MHS bring alive the stories of America 's past through a series of changing exhibitions and public programs that are free and open to the public .
#Text=Thomas Jefferson 's handwritten copy of the Declaration of Independence is a particularly significant piece in their collection .
#Text=Many famous people sit on the board of directors , including professor Henry Louis Gates , Jr. , historian Doris Kearns Goodwin , and director Ken Burns .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Warren Anatomical Museum ( Countway Library of Medicine ) , 10 Shattuck Street ( T : Brigham Circle ) , ☏ +1 617-432-6196 , ✉ chm@hms.harvard.edu .
#Text=M - F 9AM-5PM .
#Text=This small exhibition is tucked away on the 5th floor of Harvard Medical School 's Countway Library of Medicine .
#Text=It was designed by Mr. Warren in the mid 1800s to teach his medical students about anatomy .
#Text=The real highlight here — among the charts , specimens and 19th century medical instruments — is the skull of Phineas Gage .
#Text=Phineas improbably survived 12 years after a large iron bar was driven through his brain .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Panopticon Gallery ( Hotel Commonwealth ) , 502c Commonwealth Ave ( T : Kenmore ) , ☏ +1 781-718-5777 .
#Text=Tu - Sa 9AM-3PM .
#Text=Founded in 1971 , Panopticon Gallery is one of the oldest galleries in the United States dedicated solely to fine art photography .
#Text=The gallery specializes in 20th Century American Photography and emerging contemporary works .
#Text=Check their calendar for up to date information on their current exhibition .
#Text=They also carry many interesting , hard to find , fine art books in their store .
